claim: If a process repeats every 12 days, it occurs on both day 24 and day 36

supporting.text: Day 24 is a multiple of 12 (12 * 2 = 24), so the process repeats on day 24.

attacks.text: Day 24 is a multiple of 12 (12 * 2 = 24), so the process repeats on day 24.
The process may have exceptions or conditions that prevent it from occurring on every multiple of 12.
Unless explicitly stated, there is no evidence to suggest exceptions to the repeating process.
The process might only repeat on certain multiples of 12, not all.
The claim specifies that the process repeats every 12 days, implying all multiples of 12.

supporting.text: Day 36 is a multiple of 12 (12 * 3 = 36), so the process repeats on day 36.

attacks.text: Day 36 is a multiple of 12 (12 * 3 = 36), so the process repeats on day 36.
The process might have a starting offset, meaning it doesn't necessarily align with day 0.
If the process starts on day 0, then it will indeed repeat on day 36 as it is a multiple of 12.
The process could be conditional and not guaranteed to repeat every 12 days under all circumstances.
Assuming the process is unconditional and strictly periodic, it will repeat every 12 days without exception.

supporting.text: A process repeating every 12 days will occur on all integer multiples of 12, which includes both 24 and 36.

attacks.text: A process repeating every 12 days will occur on all integer multiples of 12, which includes both 24 and 36.
If the process starts on an odd-numbered day, it may not align with the 12-day cycle on day 24 or 36.
The definition of 'repeats every 12 days' implies periodicity from day 0, making the starting day irrelevant for integer multiples.
External disruptions (e.g., system failure) could prevent the process from occurring on day 24 or 36 despite the 12-day cycle.
The claim assumes ideal conditions; disruptions are edge cases and don't invalidate the mathematical periodicity.

supporting.text: Since 24 and 36 are both divisible by 12 with no remainder, the process must occur on these days.

attacks.text: Since 24 and 36 are both divisible by 12 with no remainder, the process must occur on these days.
The process may have exceptions or conditions that prevent it from occurring on certain multiples of 12.
Unless explicitly stated, there is no evidence to suggest exceptions to the process's periodicity.
If the process started on an offset day (e.g., day 5), it would not occur on day 24 or 36 unless adjusted.
The claim assumes the process starts on day 0, which is a common default unless specified otherwise.
